abstract.p: Richard B Reichart letter comments on May 11 article on Japanese Garden at Brooklyn Botanic Garden

block.p: Your article ''Revealing a Japanese Garden as Serene Melting Pot'' (May 11) gives insufficient attention to the lengthy developmental history of ''the'' Japanese garden (May 18). The widely varied concepts and practices in Japanese garden design have been affected by changes in sacred beliefs, in political and social organization and in technology over more than 15 centuries in Japan.

Your article ''Revealing a Japanese Garden as Serene Melting Pot'' (May 11) gives insufficient attention to the lengthy developmental history of ''the'' Japanese garden (May 18). The widely varied concepts and practices in Japanese garden design have been affected by changes in sacred beliefs, in political and social organization and in technology over more than 15 centuries in Japan.

Readers may wish to peruse Marc P. Keane's book ''Japanese Garden Design'' (Charles E. Tuttle, 1996). Mr. Keane, who is my cousin, is an adjunct professor at Kyoto University of Art and Design. He not only was a consultant to the Japanese Hill-and-Pond Garden at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, but also is an active practitioner who has designed and built numerous other prize-winning public and private gardens in both Japan and the United States.
